data.description: The video screen consists of two videos. The actions on both videos are synchronized. The left one is a record of the experiment with straight-up block, and the right one is a record of the experiment with the spinning block. First, on both videos there is the full view of the experimental setup and Catrina is under the table of the experimental setup and is shooting to the experimental blocks. The video has normal rate and experimental blocks on the both parts rise up and fall down very quickly. Next, the same experiments are shown in black and white in a slow motion. First, both blocks are suspended on their Plexiglas sheets. Then appears a smoke of shot. After that, the blocks start rising up simultaneously. The block on the left video moves straight-up as it was when it was suspended. Oppositely, the block on the right video rises up and rotates around its center of mass in a counterclockwise direction in screen plane. The both blocks move synchronically at the same height. When both blocks reach the top point of their trajectory, a horizontal red line appears on the screen between the blocks, connecting their centers of masses. It shows that both blocks reach the same height. Then blocks slowly fall down.

data.content:
Linear momentum is conserved in the bullet/block collision, regardless of where the bullet hits the block. The result is that both blocks will have the same upward momentum and each block's center-of-mass will rise to the same height.

Since the spinning block has more kinetic energy than the non-spinning block, less of the bullet's original energy is available to deform the wood in the spinning block (e.g., the bullet may not penetrate as far).
